headline.print_headline: For U.S. Troops At War, Liquor Is Spur to Crime
headline.main: For U.S. Troops at War, Liquor Is Spur to Crime

docs.lead_paragraph: Strictly forbidden by the U.S. military in Iraq and Afghanistan, alcohol is a factor in a growing number of crimes by troops.
docs.snippet: Strictly forbidden by the U.S. military in Iraq and Afghanistan, alcohol is a factor in a growing number of crimes by troops.

headline.print_headline: Suicide Found to Be Less Likely in Heavier People
headline.main: On the Scales: 	Suicide Found to Be Less Likely in Heavier People

docs.lead_paragraph: Health researchers have found a strong association between higher body mass index and a lower risk of suicide.
docs.snippet: Health researchers have found a strong association between higher body mass index and a lower risk of suicide.

headline.main: Suicide Found to Be Less Likely in Heavier People

docs.abstract: Dr Kenneth J Mukamal, Harvard University associate professor, leads study that finds people with higher body mass index are at lower risk of suicide than those people who are not overweight; research is published in Archives of Internal medicine (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: That fat people are jolly is almost certainly a myth, but a study published yesterday has found a strong association between higher body mass index, or B.M.I., and lower risk of suicide. In a 16-year study that followed more than 45,000 male health professionals, researchers found a steady decrease in suicides as B.M.I. increased, even after controlling for variables including smoking, dietary factors, physical activity, marital status and alcohol use. There were 131 suicides during the time of the study.
docs.snippet: That fat people are jolly is almost certainly a myth, but a study published yesterday has found a strong association between higher body mass index, or B.M.I., and lower risk of suicide.     In a 16-year study that followed more than 45,000 male...

headline.print_headline: Teaching Even the Pickiest Toddlers How to Eat Their Vegetables and Love It
headline.main: Teaching Even the Pickiest Toddlers How to Eat Their Vegetables and Love It

docs.lead_paragraph: The eat-what-you-want approach is a critical part of the curriculum at the Nutritional Sciences Preschool, which is dedicated to developing toddlers’ healthy eating habits.
